intro: Bryophyllum ambrense, commonly known as the "mother of thousands," is a succulent plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the Crassulaceae family and is characterized by its thick, fleshy leaves that store water, allowing it to thrive in arid environments. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers on terminal spikes, which are pollinated by insects. One of its most distinctive features is the production of plantlets along the edges of its leaves, which can take root and grow into new plants. This ability to propagate vegetatively makes it a popular choice for gardeners and a fascinating subject in botanical studies.
